text: Wherever I’ve moved within all of Israel, did I ever ask even one judge of Israel whom I commanded to shepherd my people, ‘Why haven’t you built me a cedar house?’”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now therefore this is what you are to tell my servant David: 
‘This is what the Lord of the Heavenly Armies says: “I took you from the pasture myself—from tending sheep—to become Commander-in-Chief over my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘“Furthermore, I have remained with you everywhere you have gone, annihilating all your enemies right in front of you. I will make your reputation great, like the reputation of the great ones who have lived on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish a homeland for my people Israel, planting them in a secure location where they will never be disturbed anymore. Wicked people will not oppress them as happened in the past,
speaker: Narrator

text:
during the time I had commanded judges to administer my people Israel. I’ll also grant you deliverance from all your enemies.
“‘“I’m also announcing to you that the Lord also will himself build a house for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will come about that when your life is complete and you go to join your ancestors, I will raise up your offspring after you, who is related to one of your sons, and I will fortify his kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will build a temple dedicated to me, and I will make his throne last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be a father to him and he will be a son to me. I will never remove my gracious love from him as I did from the one who preceded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will confirm him in my Temple and in my kingdom forever, and his throne will remain secure forever.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Using precisely these words, Nathan communicated this complete oracle to David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then King David went in, sat down in the presence of the Lord, and said:
“Who am I, Lord God, and what is my household, since you have brought me to this?
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, this is a small thing to you, God, and yet you have spoken concerning your servant’s household for a great while to come, and you have seen in me the fulfillment of man’s purpose, Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What more can David say to you about how you are honoring your servant, and you surely know your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lord, for the sake of your servant, and consistent with your heart, you have done all of these great things and are now making these great things known.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Lord, there is no one like you, and we have heard from no god other than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: What other one nation on the earth is like your people Israel, God, which you have redeemed from slavery to become your own people, making a great name for yourself when you redeemed your people from Egypt. You did awesome miraculous deeds, driving out nations that stood in their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took your people Israel to be your very own people forever, and you, Lord, have become their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, Lord, let what you have spoken concerning your servant and his household be done forever—and let it be done just as you’ve promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: May your name be made great and honored forever: The Lord of the Heavenly Armies, the God of Israel, is God for Israel, and may the family of David your servant stand before you forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Because of you, my God, I have been bold to pray to you, as you have told your servant that you will build him a dynasty.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, Lord, you are God, and you have promised all of these good things to your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, it has pleased you to bless the dynasty of your servant, so that it will continue in place forever in your presence, because when you, Lord, grant a blessing, it is an eternal blessing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, David defeated and subdued the Philistines, and then took possession of Gath and its towns from Philistine control.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also conquered Moab, placing them in servitude and making them pay tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also defeated King Hadadezer of Zobah, which is near Hamath, while he was going about establishing his hegemony as far as the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text: David confiscated 1,000 chariots, 7,000 horsemen, and 20,000 foot soldiers from him, and hamstrung all of the chariot horses except for a reserve force of 100 chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Arameans came from Damascus to help King Hadadezer of Zobah, David killed 22,000 of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: David later erected garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and the Arameans were placed under servitude to David, to whom they paid tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also confiscated the gold shields that belonged to Hadadezer’s officials and took them to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also confiscated a vast quantity of bronze from Tibhath and Cun, cities under Hadadezer’s control. Later on, Solomon crafted the bronze sea, the pillars, and the bronze vessels for the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Tou of Hamath learned that David had conquered King Hadadezer of Zobah’s entire army,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent his son Hadoram to King David to meet and congratulate him, because he had fought against and defeated Hadadezer. Since Hadadezer had often been to war against Tou, he sent all sorts of gold, silver, and bronze goods
speaker: Narrator

text: to King David, which David also dedicated to the Lord, along with silver and gold that he confiscated from all the surrounding nations, including Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and Amalek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s son Abishai killed 18,000 Edomites in the Salt Valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: He erected garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became subservient to David, while the Lord gave victory to David wherever he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David reigned over all of Israel, administering justice and equity to all of his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s son Joab served in charge of the army, Ahilud’s son Jehoshaphat was his personal archivist,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahitub’s son Zadok and Abiathar’s son Ahimelech were priests, Shavsha was his personal secretary,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah supervised the special forces and mercenaries, while David’s sons worked as chief officials in service to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, King Nahash of Ammon died and his son succeeded him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so David told himself, “I will be loyal to Nahash’s son Hanun, since his father showed loyal, gracious love to me.” So David sent a delegation to console him about his loss of his father.
But when David’s delegation arrived to visit Hanun in Ammonite territory to console him,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Ammonite officials asked Hanun, “Do you think that because David has sent a delegation of consolers to you that he is honoring your father? His delegation has arrived to search, overthrow, and scout the land, hasn’t it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hanun arrested David’s delegation, shaved off their beards, cut off their clothes at the waist line, and sent them away in disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they had departed, David was informed about the men, so he sent word to them, since they had been deeply humiliated. He told them, “Stay at Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites realized that they had created quite a stink with David, Hanun and the Ammonites spent 1,000 silver talents to hire chariots and mercenaries from Mesopotamia, from Aram-maacah, and from Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hired 32,000 chariots, along with the king of Maacah and his army, who arrived and encamped at Medeba. The Ammonites also were mustered and came out to battle from their home cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: In response, David sent out Joab and his entire army of elite soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites went out in battle formation in front of the entrance to the city while the kings who had come stayed by themselves in the open fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab observed that the battle lines were set up to oppose him both in front and behind, he appointed some special forces from Israel and arrayed them to oppose the Arameans,
speaker: Narrator

text: putting the rest of his forces under command of his brother Abishai, who arrayed them to oppose the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told Abishai, “If the Arameans prove too strong for me, then you are to help me. If the Ammonites prove too strong for you, then I will help you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong, be courageous on behalf of our people and for the cities of our God, and may the Lord do what he thinks is best.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab and the soldiers who were with him attacked the Arameans in battle formation, and the Arameans retreated in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites saw the Arameans retreating, they also retreated from Joab’s brother Abishai back to the city and Joab left for Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Arameans realized that they had been defeated by Israel, they sent for the Arameans who lived beyond the Euphrates River. Shophach was leading them as commander of Hadadezer’s army.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David learned this, he mustered all of Israel, crossed the Jordan, approached the Arameans, and drew up his forces against them. After David had assembled in battle array against the Arameans, the Arameans attacked him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Arameans retreated from Israel, and David’s forces killed 7,000 Aramean charioteers, 40,000 soldiers, and Shophach, the commander of their army.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hadadezer’s officials saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they sought terms of peace with David and became subservient to him. After this, the Arameans were unwilling to help the Ammonites anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later the next spring, at the time that kings go out to fight, Joab led out the army, ravaged the territory of the Ammonites, and then went out and attacked Rabbah, while David remained behind in Jerusalem. Joab besieged Rabbah and conquered it.
speaker: Narrator

text: David confiscated the crown of their king from his head, and found that its weight was a talent in gold. A precious stone had been set in it, and it was placed on David’s head. He also confiscated a great amount of war booty that had been plundered from the city,
speaker: Narrator

text: brought back the people who had lived in it, and put them to conscripted labor with saws, iron picks, and axes. David did this to every Ammonite city, and then David and his entire army returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, war broke out against the Philistines at Gezer, where Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Sippai, one of the descendants of the Rephaim, defeating the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was also another battle against the Philistines, when Jair’s son Elhanan killed Lahmi the Gittite, Goliath’s brother, whose spear was as big as a weaver’s beam.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was also a battle at Gath, where there was a very tall man with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—for a total of 24 digits—who was a descendant of the Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he challenged Israel, Shimei’s son Jonathan, David’s nephew, killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These descendants from the giants in Gath died at the hands of David and his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Satan attacked Israel by inciting David to enumerate a census of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David ordered Joab and the commanders of the army, “Go take a census of Israel from Beer-sheba to Dan, and bring me a report so I can be aware of the total number.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab replied, “May the Lord increase the population of his people a hundredfold! Your majesty, all of them are your majesty’s servants, aren’t they? So why should your majesty demand this? Why should he bring guilt to Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king’s order overruled Joab, so Joab left, traveled throughout all of Israel, and then returned to Jerusalem
speaker: Narrator

text: to report the total population count to David. Throughout all of Israel there were 1,100,000 men trained for war. In Judah there were 470,000 men trained for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Levi and Benjamin were not included in the census, because what the king had commanded was unethical to Joab.
speaker: Narrator

text: God considered this behavior to be evil, so he attacked Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David responded to God, “I sinned greatly by behaving this way. But now I am asking you, please remove the guilt of your servant, since I have acted very foolishly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord responded through Gad, David’s seer.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and tell David, ‘This is what the Lord says: “I’m holding three choices out for you: pick one of them for yourself, and I will do it to you.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gad went to David and told him, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Make a choice for yourself:
speaker: Narrator

text: Either three years of famine, or three months of reversals as you are swept away by your enemies while the sword of your enemies overtakes you, or three days with the sword of the Lord, consisting of pestilence infecting the land, with the angel of the Lord wreaking destruction from border to border throughout all of Israel.’ Decide right now what I am to answer to the one who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David replied to Gad, “This is a very bad choice for me to make! Let me now please fall into the hand of the Lord, because his mercy is very great, but may I never fall into human hands!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord sent a pestilence to Israel, and 70,000 men died in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God also sent an angel to destroy Jerusalem, but as he was about to do so, the Lord looked and withdrew the calamity by saying to the destroying angel, “Enough! Stop what you’re doing!”
So the angel of the Lord remained standing near the threshing floor that belonged to Ornan the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: David looked up and saw the angel of the Lord standing between earth and heaven, with a drawn sword in his hand stretched out over Jerusalem. Then David and the elders, clothed in sackcloth, fell on their faces.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told God, “Wasn’t I the one who ordered the census of the population? Wasn’t it I who sinned and acted wickedly? Now as for these sheep, what have they done? Lord God, please let your hand be against me and my ancestral household, but don’t let your people be ravaged by plague!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord told Gad to tell David that David was to go up and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor that belonged to Ornan the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up, obeying Gad’s directive that he had spoken in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ornan turned around and saw the angel. While his four sons with him ran away to hide, Ornan continued to thresh wheat.
speaker: Narrator

text: As David approached Ornan, Ornan looked around and observed David, left the threshing floor, and fell to the ground before David with his face on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Ornan, “Give me the threshing floor as a site to build an altar to the Lord on it. Give it to me at its full price, so the plague may be averted from the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ornan replied to David, “Take it! Let your majesty the king do whatever seems like a good idea to him. Look here! I’m giving the oxen for burnt offerings, the threshing machinery for the wood, and the wheat for a grain offering. I’m giving all of it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But King David told Ornan, “No. I will buy them for the full price because I will not offer to the Lord what is yours or offer burnt offerings that cost me nothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David paid Ornan 600 shekels weight worth in gold for the site,
speaker: Narrator

text: built an altar to the Lord there, and presented burnt offerings and peace offerings. He called out to the Lord, and he answered him from heaven with fire on the altar of burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, the Lord spoke to the angel, who then sheathed his sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: From that time on, after David had observed that the Lord had answered him at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he made his sacrifices there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the tent of the Lord that Moses had crafted in the desert, along with the altar of burnt offerings, were being stored at the high place in Gibeon at that time,
speaker: Narrator

text: but David was not going before it to inquire of God, because he was afraid of the sword carried by the angel of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “This is where the Lord God’s Temple will be, along with the altar of burnt offerings for Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David subsequently issued orders to conscript the resident aliens who lived in the land of Israel and appointed stonecutters to prepare stones for building a temple for God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also provisioned abundant supplies of iron for nails to build the doors for gates and to build clamps. Furthermore, he provided so much bronze it wasn’t inventoried,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as an innumerable amount of cedar logs, since the Sidonians and Tyrians brought vast amounts of cedar to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David thought, “My son Solomon is young and inexperienced. The temple that will be built for the Lord is to be magnificent, well known, and internationally honored, so I will complete preparations for it.” So before his death, David finished providing a great quantity of materials for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, David called for his son Solomon and directed him to build a temple to the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David addressed Solomon: “I have attempted to build a temple to the name of the Lord my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But this message from the Lord came to me, telling me
‘You have shed a lot of blood and fought great battles. You won’t be building a house for my name, since you have shed so much blood on the earth in my sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: But look! A son born to you will live comfortably, because I will give him rest from all his enemies that surround him on every side, since his name will be “Solomon”—I will give peace and quiet for Israel during his lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will build a temple to my name. He will be a son to me, I myself will be a father to him, and I will secure his royal throne in Israel forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, my son, may the Lord be with you, so that you are successful in constructing the Temple of the Lord your God, just as he has spoken about you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Only may the Lord give you discretion and understanding as he places you in charge over Israel, so you can keep the Law of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will be successful, if you keep on observing the statutes and ordinances that the Lord commanded Moses concerning Israel. Be strong, be courageous, and never give in to fear or dismay.
speaker: Narrator

text: At great effort I have provided for the Temple of the Lord 100,000 gold talents, 1,000,000 silver talents, as well as bronze and iron beyond calculation, since there is so much of it. I’ve also provided timber and stone, but you’ll need to obtain more.
speaker: Narrator

text: You already have plenty of workers, including stonecutters, masons, carpenters, and an innumerable group of artisans who are skilled at working in
speaker: Narrator

text: gold, silver, bronze, and iron. So begin the work, and may the Lord be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David also issued these orders to all of the leaders of Israel to assist his son Solomon:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Isn’t the Lord your God with you? Hasn’t he surrounded you with comfort? He has delivered the inhabitants of the land into my control, and the land lies subdued both in the Lord’s presence and before his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So set your minds and hearts to seek the Lord your God, to get up, and to build the sanctuary of the Lord God, so the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord and the holy vessels of God may be stored in a temple built for the name of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After David had reached old age, and had completed his reign, he set his son Solomon as king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David then gathered together all of the leaders of Israel, including the priests and descendants of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: descendants of Levi 30 years old and above were counted for a total of 38,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: “24,000 of these,” David said, “are to be set in charge of the work of the Temple of the Lord, with 6,000 serving as officers and judges,
speaker: Narrator

text: with 4,000 gatekeepers, and with 4,000 offering praises to the Lord with the musical instruments that I have had crafted.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David divided them into divisions based on Gershon, Kohath, and Merari, Levi’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershon were Ladan and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three descendants of Ladan included Jehiel (their chief), Zetham, and Joel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three descendants of Shimei included Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran. These were the heads of families of Ladan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shimei included Jahath, Zina, Jeush, and Beriah. These four were sons of Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahath served as chief and Zizah was second in rank, but since Jeush and Beriah did not have many sons, they were enrolled as a single family unit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four descendants of Kohath included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Amram included Aaron and Moses. Aaron had been set apart to consecrate the most holy things, with the intent that he and his sons should present offerings in the Lord’s presence forever, ministering to him and pronouncing blessings in his name forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, as for Moses the man of God, his sons were considered among the tribe of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Moses included Gershom and Eliezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershom included Shebuel as their chief.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Eliezer included Rehabiah as their chief. Eliezer had no other sons, but Rehabiah had many descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Izhar included Shelomith their chief.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Hebron included Jeriah their chief, Amariah their second in rank, Jahaziel their third, and Jekameam their fourth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Uzziel included Micah their chief and Isshiah their second in rank.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Merari included Mahli and Mushi. The descendants of Mahli included Eleazar and Kish,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Eleazar died having no sons, but only daughters. Their relatives (the descendants of Kish) married them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The three descendants of Mushi included Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Levi according to their ancestral households, with family heads documented according to the names of persons 20 years and older who were appointed to perform work in service to the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For David had said “The Lord God of Israel has granted rest to his people, and he has taken Israel as his eternal residence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the descendants of Levi are no longer to carry the Tent or its service implements.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Since, according to David’s final instructions, the list above contains the total number of descendants of Levi from the age of 20 years and upward,
speaker: Narrator

text:
David issued these orders:
“Instead, they are to assist by lending a hand to the descendants of Aaron regarding service to the Temple of the Lord relating to the courts, the chambers, purification of everything pertaining to holiness, and to anything else pertaining to service on behalf of the Temple of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: including assisting with the rows of showbread, selecting flour for the grain offerings, the unleavened bread, baked offerings, and oil-based offerings, no matter what the quantity or sizes.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to take their stand morning by morning, thanking and praising the Lord right through until the evening,
speaker: Narrator

text: whenever burnt offerings are presented to the Lord, whether on Sabbaths, New Moons, or scheduled festivals, regularly in the Lord’s presence in accordance with the number required to conduct their service.
speaker: Narrator

text: By doing this, they will fulfill their obligation as trustees over the Tent of Assembly and the Sanctuary, attending to the needs of their relatives, who are descendants of Aaron, in keeping with their service on behalf of the Temple of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: With respect to the descendants of Aaron, classes of service were organized for Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar, the descendants of Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nadab and Abihu died before their father did, leaving no sons, so Eleazar and Ithamar became priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along with Zadok, one of Eleazar’s descendants, and Ahimelech, one of Ithamar’s descendants, David organized their service according to their assigned responsibilities.
speaker: Narrator

text: More leaders were located among Eleazar’s descendants than among those of Ithamar, so sixteen leaders were appointed from the leaders of the ancestral households of Eleazar’s descendants and eight from those of Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were chosen by impartial lottery, since there were trustees of the sanctuary and officers of God among both Eleazar’s descendants and among Ithamar’s descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nethanel’s son Shemaiah, a Levitical scribe, made an official record of them for the king, the officers, Zadok the priest, Abiathar’s son Ahimelech, and the heads of ancestral households of both the priests and the descendants of Levi. One ancestral house was chosen for Eleazar and one for Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first lottery was chosen in favor of Jehoiarib, the second for Jedaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: third for Harim, the fourth for Seorim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifth for Malchijah, the sixth for Mijamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventh for Hakkoz, the eighth for Abijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the ninth for Jeshua, the tenth for Shecaniah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eleventh for Eliashib, the twelfth for Jakim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the thirteenth for Huppah, the fourteenth for Jeshebeab,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifteenth for Bilgah, the sixteenth for Immer,
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventeenth for Hezir, the eighteenth for Happizzez,
speaker: Narrator

text: the nineteenth for Pethahiah, the twentieth for Jehezkel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-first for Jachin, the twenty-second for Gamul,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-third for Delaiah, and the twenty-fourth for Maaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were appointed to enter the Temple of the Lord according to their protocols established by their ancestor Aaron, as commanded by the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now with respect to the descendants of Levi there remained Shubael from the descendants of Amram and Jehdeiah from the descendants of Shubael;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to Rehabiah, Isshiah their chief from the descendants Rehabiah;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to the Izharites, Shelomoth, Jahath from the descendants of Shelomoth;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to the descendants of Hebron, Jeriah their chief, Amariah their second in rank, Jahaziel their third, and Jekameam their fourth;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to the descendants of Uzziel, Micah; with respect to the descendants of Micah, Shamir;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to Micah’s brother Isshiah; with respect to the descendants of Isshiah, Zechariah;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to Merari’s sons, Mahli and Mushi; with respect to the sons of Jaaziah, Beno;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to the sons of Merari, Jaaziah, Beno, Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to Mahli, Eleazar, who had no sons;
speaker: Narrator

text: with respect to Kish, Jerahmeel, one of the descendants of Kish;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with respect to the descendants of Mushi, Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth. These were the descendants of Levi according to their ancestral households.
speaker: Narrator

text: These individuals also cast lots corresponding to their relatives, Aaron’s descendants, in the presence of King David, Zadok, and Ahimelech, and in the presence of the heads of the ancestral households of the priests and of the descendants of Levi, and the eldest was treated as impartially as was the younger brother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Along with officers in his army, David consecrated to assist in service to the descendants of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun those who prophesy with lyres, harps, and cymbals.
The list of those who participated in this service included:
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Asaph: Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah, sons of Asaph mentored by Asaph himself, who prophesied under the supervision of the king;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Jeduthun, these six of his descendants: Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah, mentored by their father Jeduthun, who played a lyre and prophesied, giving thanks and praise to the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Heman, these descendants: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamti-ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these were descendants of Heman the king’s seer, according to God’s promise to exalt him, since God had given Heman fourteen sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were all under their father’s supervision regarding music in the Temple of the Lord with cymbals, harps, and lyres for the service of the Temple of God.
Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman were under command of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: They and their relatives who had been skillfully trained in singing to the Lord, numbered 288.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their duties, whether significant or insignificant, whether performed by teacher or pupil alike, were assigned by lottery.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asaph’s first lottery was cast in favor of Joseph; the second went to Gedaliah, that is, to him, to his relatives, and his sons, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the third to Zaccur, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the fourth to Izri, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifth to Nethaniah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the sixth to Bukkiah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventh to Jesharelah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the eighth to Jeshaiah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the ninth to Mattaniah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the tenth to Shimei, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the eleventh to Azarel, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the twelfth to Hashabiah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the thirteenth to Shubael, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the fourteenth to Mattithiah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifteenth to Jeremoth, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the sixteenth to Hananiah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventeenth to Joshbekashah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the eighteenth to Hanani, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the nineteenth to Mallothi, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the twentieth to Eliathah, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-first to Hothir, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-second to Giddalti, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-third to Mahazioth, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve;
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-fourth to Romamti-ezer, his sons and his relatives, for a total of twelve.
speaker: Narrator

text: The guild of trustees included, from the descendants of Korah, Kore’s son Meshelemiah from Asaph’s descendants;
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshelemiah’s sons Zechariah, his firstborn, Jediael his second, Zebadiah his third, Jathniel his fourth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elam his fifth, Jehohanan his sixth, and Eliehoenai his seventh;
speaker: Narrator

text: Obed-edom’s sons Shemaiah, his firstborn, Jehozabad his second, Joah his third, Sachar his fourth, Nethanel his fifth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ammiel his sixth, Issachar his seventh, and Peullethai his eighth, since God had blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, his son Shemaiah had sons born to him who wielded authority in their ancestral households, since they were mighty men of valor.
speaker: Narrator

text: These sons of Shemaiah included Othni, Rephael, Obed, and Elzabad, whose brothers were valiant, able men, Elihu and Semachiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these sons of Obed-edom, along with their sons and brothers, were valiant men, fully qualified for duty—62 descendants of Obed-edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshelemiah had 18 sons and brothers who were valiant men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hosah, one of Merari’s sons, had these sons: Shimri their chief (though not the firstborn, his father had appointed him chief),
speaker: Narrator

text: Hilkiah his second, Tebaliah his third, and Zechariah his fourth, with a total of 13 sons and brothers of Hosah.
speaker: Narrator

text: With respect to their leaders, these courses of trustees had responsibilities, along with their relatives, regarding ministry within the Temple of the Lord
speaker: Narrator

text: assigned by lottery according to their ancestral households, whether large or small alike, for their gate assignments.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lot for the eastern gate fell to Shelemiah. They also cast lots for his son Zechariah, who was a wise counselor, and his lot indicated the northern gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obed-edom’s lot indicated the south gate, and his sons were also allotted responsibility for the storehouse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Shuppim and Hosah the lot indicated the west at the gate of Shallecheth on the ascending road.
Each guard corresponding to each guard,
speaker: Narrator

text: on the east six descendants of Levi were assigned for each day, on the north four for each day, on the south four for each day (as well as two pairs of guards assigned to the storehouse),
speaker: Narrator

text: and for the colonnade on the west four were assigned at the road and two at the colonnade.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the ranks of trustees assigned among the descendants of Korah and the sons of Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now with respect to the descendants of Levi, Ahijah was responsible for the treasuries of the Temple of God, including the treasuries containing dedicated gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: With respect to the descendants of Ladan, the Gershonite descendants pertaining to Ladan, the heads of families pertaining to Ladan the Gershonite, there was Jehieli.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Jehieli, Zetham and his brother Joel, were responsible for the treasuries of the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel were assigned
speaker: Narrator

text: Shebuel, a descendant of Gershom and a descendant of Moses (as chief officer in charge of the treasuries)
speaker: Narrator

text: and his brothers from Eliezer, including his son Rehabiah, his son Jeshaiah, his son Joram, his son Zichri, and his son Shelomoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelomoth and his brothers were responsible for all of the treasuries of dedicated gifts given by King David, by the heads of families, by the officers of groups of thousands and groups of hundreds, and by the leading army officers.
speaker: Narrator

text: They dedicated gifts for the maintenance of the Temple of the Lord from spoils of war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, everything that Samuel the seer, Kish’s son Saul, Ner’s son Abner, and Zeruiah’s son Joab had dedicated—all of their dedicated gifts—were under the care of Shelomoth and his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Izhar, Chenaniah and his sons were assigned as officers and judges with responsibilities relating to external duties.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Hebron, Hashabiah and his relatives—1,700 outstanding men—were assigned oversight of Israel west of the Jordan regarding all of the Lord’s work and services on behalf of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Hebron, Jerijah was assigned chief of the descendants of Hebron. During the fortieth year of David’s administration, a search was made by genealogical record, family by family, to find men of great ability, including those found at Jazer in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: King David appointed Jerijah, his relatives, and 2,700 competent men who were each family heads, to oversee the tribes of Reuben and Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh regarding everything pertaining to God as well as matters relating to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelis, according to the number of the leaders of their families, the officers of groups of thousands and groups of hundreds, and their leaders who served the king on behalf of the army divisions of 24,000 soldiers on duty month by month throughout the year, consisted of the following.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zabdiel’s son Jashobeam was responsible for the first division of 24,000 soldiers for the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: A descendant of Perez, he was chief of all the commanders of the army for the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dodai the Ahohite was responsible for the division of the second month. Mikloth served as chief officer of his division, consisting of 24,000 soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah the priest was commander of the third division for the third month, consisting of 24,000 soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the same Benaiah who was one of the elite men of the Thirty and in command of the Thirty. His son Ammizabad was responsible for his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab’s brother Asahel was fourth for the fourth month, assisted by his son Zebadiah, with 24,000 soldiers in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth commander for the fifth month was Shamhuth the Izrahite. His division consisted of 24,000 soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ikkesh’s son Ira from Tekoa was sixth for the sixth month; there were 24,000 soldiers in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Helez the Pelonite, an Ephraimite, was seventh for the seventh month; 24,000 soldiers served in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sibbecai the Hushathite, a Zerahite, was eighth for the eighth month; 24,000 soldiers served in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiezer from Anathoth, a descendant of Benjamin, was ninth for the ninth month; 24,000 soldiers served in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahari from Netophah, a Zerahite, was tenth for the tenth month; 24,000 soldiers served in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah from Pirathon, an Ephraimite, was eleventh for the eleventh month; 24,000 soldiers served in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heldai the Netophathite, from Othniel, was twelfth for the twelfth month; 24,000 soldiers served in his division.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wielding the scepters of Israel for the descendants of Reuben, there was Zichri’s son Eliezer as chief officer; for the descendants of Simeon there was Maacah’s son Shephatiah;
speaker: Narrator

text: for Levi there was Kemuel’s son Hashabiah; for Aaron there was Zadok;
speaker: Narrator

text: for Judah there was Elihu, one of David’s brothers; for Issachar there was Michael’s son Omri;
speaker: Narrator

text: for Zebulun there was Obadiah’s son Ishmaiah; for Naphtali, there was Azriel’s son Jerimoth;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the descendants of Ephraim, there was Azaziah’s son Hoshea; for the half-tribe of Manasseh, there was Pedaiah’s son Joel;
speaker: Narrator

text: for the half-tribe of Manasseh in Gilead, there was Zechariah’s son Iddo; for Benjamin, there was Abner’s son Jaasiel;
speaker: Narrator

text: for Dan, there was Jeroham’s son Azarel. These were the leaders of the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David did not complete a census of those younger than 20 years of age, since the Lord had said he would make Israel as numerous as the stars of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zeruiah’s son Joab began the census, but never completed it. Nevertheless, God became angry with Israel because of this, so the number was never entered into the official records of the Annals of King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adiel’s son Azmaveth was responsible for the king’s treasuries. Uzziah’s son Jonathan was in charge of treasuries located in the country, in cities, in villages, and in towers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Chelub’s son Ezri supervised the field workers who tilled the soil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei the Ramathite supervised the vineyards. In charge over the produce of the vineyards for the wine cellars was Zabdi the Shiphmite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baal-hanan the Gederite supervised the olive and sycamore trees in the Shephelah. Joash supervised the oil reserves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shitrai the Sharonite supervised the herds that were pastured in Sharon. Adlai’s son Shaphat supervised the herds in the valleys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obil the Ishmaelite supervised the camels. Jehdeiah the Meronothite supervised the donkeys. Jaziz the Hagrite supervised the flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these served as stewards over King David’s property.
speaker: Narrator

text: David’s uncle Jonathan was a counselor, since he was a man of understanding and a scribe, and Hachmoni’s son Jehiel was an attendant to the king’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel served as an advisor to the king, Hushai the Archite was the king’s trusted associate,
speaker: Narrator

text: and under Ahithophel there was Benaiah’s son Jehoiada and Abiathar. Joab served as commander of the king’s army.
speaker: Narrator

text: David gathered together all of the leaders of Israel, the leaders of the tribes, division officers who reported to the king, the commanders of thousands, commanders of hundreds, the supervisors of the property and livestock that belonged to the king and to his sons, along with all of the officers of the palace, the elite forces, and all of the soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: King David rose to his feet and said, “My fellow citizens, may I have your attention. I intended to build a house of rest for the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, for a footstool of our God, so I began preparations for its construction.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then God told me, ‘You will not build a temple to my name, because you are a man of war, and you have committed bloodshed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the Lord God of Israel chose me from my entire ancestral household to be king over Israel forever, since he had chosen Judah as Commander-in-Chief. In my ancestor Judah’s household, from my father’s household, and from among my father’s sons it pleased him to make me king over all of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now out of all of my sons (since the Lord has given me many of them), he has selected my son Solomon to sit on the throne of the kingdom of the Lord, ruling over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He told me,
‘I chose your son Solomon to be the one who will construct my Temple and my courts, because I have chosen him to be a son to me, and I will be a father to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish his kingdom forever, assuming he remains strongly committed to carry out my commandments and ordinances, as he is doing today.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, in the presence of all of Israel, the assembly of the Lord, and while our God is listening, observe and search through all of the commandments of the Lord your God, so that you may continue to possess this good land, leaving it for an inheritance forever to benefit your descendants who come after you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now as for you, my son Solomon, get to know the God of your father. Serve him with a sound heart and a devoted soul, because the Lord is searching every heart, every plan and thought. He will be found by you, assuming you are seeking him, but if you abandon him, he will abandon you forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: So keep watching, because the Lord has chosen you to build the Temple of his sanctuary. So be strong, and get to work!”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this point in his address, David transferred to his son Solomon the construction plans for the Hall of Justice, its buildings, its treasure vaults, its upper rooms, its inner chambers, the housing for the Mercy Seat,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the plans for everything else that he had in mind for the courtyards of the Temple of the Lord. Included were plans for all of the surrounding vaults and treasuries of the Temple of God intended for storage of dedicated gifts,
speaker: Narrator

text: for use by the ranks of priests and descendants of Levi, for all the work of service responsibilities in the Temple of the Lord, and for all of the utensils used in the work of the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also transferred to him by weight the gold that was to be used to craft the service utensils, the silver that was to be used to craft the service utensils,
speaker: Narrator

text: the gold for the golden lamp stands and their lamps, the silver for a lamp stand and its lamps (each according to its intended use in the service),
speaker: Narrator

text: the gold by weight for each table of the rows of bread, the silver for the silver tables,
speaker: Narrator

text: pure gold for the forks, the basins, the cups, the golden bowls (along with enough gold by weight for each one), enough weight for each of the silver bowls,
speaker: Narrator

text: refined gold for the altar of incense, by weight, along with his plans for crafting the golden chariot for the cherubim that spread out their wings to cover the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All of these things the Lord made clear to me in writing at his direction—the construction plans for all of the building.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David continued with these words for his son Solomon: “Be strong and courageous, and get to work. Never be afraid or discouraged, for the Lord God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you nor will he abandon you right up to your completion of the work for the service of the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look! Here are the ranks of the priests and the descendants of Levi for the entire service of the Temple of God, and in all of the work there will be all types of volunteers who have skills for anything needed for the services. Furthermore, the officers and all of the people will be at your complete command.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David addressed the entire assembly: “My son Solomon, the one whom God alone has chosen, is still young and inexperienced, and the task is great, since this structure will be a citadel to the Lord God and not for human beings.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the extent that I have been able to do so, I have provided supplies for the Temple of my God, including gold for what is to be made of gold, silver for what is to be made of silver, bronze for what is to be made of bronze, iron for what is to be made of iron, wood for what is to be made of wood, and great quantities of onyx, precious stones, antimony, colored stones, all types of other semi-precious stones, and plenty of marble.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In addition to everything that I have supplied for the Temple, it pleases me to provide my own treasure of gold and silver, so because of my love for the Temple of my God I hereby give to the Temple of my God the following:
speaker: Narrator

text: 3,000 gold talents imported from Ophir, 7,000 talents of refined silver for gilding the walls of the Temple
speaker: Narrator

text: and for all the work to be undertaken by skilled artists, gold for what is to be made of gold, and silver for what is to be made of silver. Who then, will be dedicating the productivity of his own work to the Lord today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the leaders of the ancestral households presented their voluntary offerings, as did the leaders of the tribes, the commanders of thousands and hundreds, and the officials in charge of the king’s business.
speaker: Narrator

text: They presented 5,000 gold talents and 10,000 gold darics for the work of the Temple of God, 10,000 silver talents, 18,000 bronze talents, and 100,000 iron talents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever owned precious stones gave them to the treasury of the Temple of the Lord, in care of Jehiel the Gershonite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the people rejoiced because they had given voluntarily, since with a devoted heart they had freely given to the Lord.
King David also rejoiced greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David blessed the Lord in the presence of the entire assembly. David said,
How blessed you are, Lord,
    the God of our ancestor Israel,
        from eternity to eternity!
speaker: Narrator

text:
To you, Lord, belongs the greatness, and the valor,
    and the splendor, and the endurance, and the majesty
because all that is in heaven
    and on earth is yours.
To you belongs the kingdom, Lord,
    and you are exalted as head over all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Both wealth and honor proceed from you,
    and you are ruling over them all.
You control power—
    you control who is made great,
        and how everyone becomes strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And so, our God, we are giving you thanks,
    and we are praising your wonderful name!
speaker: Narrator

text:
But who am I,
    and who are my people,
        that we make such voluntary offerings as these?
For all things come from you,
    and from your own hand we are giving to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For we are aliens and vagrants in your presence,
    as were all of our ancestors.
Our days on the earth pass away like shadows,
    and we have no hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord our God, all of this abundance that we have given
    for building a temple for your great name
was provided by you
    and all of it belongs to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I know, God,
    that it is you who searches the heart
        and you who finds pleasure in righteousness.
With a righteous heart I have freely given all these things,
    and now I have seen all of these people of yours
        giving freely and joyfully to you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lord God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, our ancestors,
    keep your purposes and thoughts
        constantly in the hearts of your people
and direct their hearts toward you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
granting to my son Solomon to keep with a devoted heart
your commands, your decrees, and your statutes,
    carrying out all of them,
and that he may build the Temple
    for which I have made the preparations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David told the entire assembly, “Bless the Lord your God, please.” So the entire assembly blessed the Lord God of their ancestors, bowing their heads and falling in the Lord’s presence and before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, they offered sacrifices and burnt offerings to the Lord amounting to 1,000 bulls, 1,000 rams, and 1,000 lambs, along with their libations. Sacrifices were abundant throughout all Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and they ate and drank in the Lord’s presence with great joy.
They crowned David’s son Solomon king a second time and anointed him to serve as Commander-in-Chief to the Lord and Zadok to serve as priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord as king in the place of his father David. He prospered, and all of Israel obeyed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the officials, all of the valiant soldiers, and all of King David’s sons submitted to King Solomon’s control,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord exalted Solomon magnificently in the sight of all Israel, bestowing upon him royal majesty such as had not been given to any king in Israel before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse’s son David reigned as king over all of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: serving as king over Israel for 40 years. He reigned for seven years in Hebron and for 33 in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He died at a good old age, having lived a full life, replete with riches and honor, and with his son Solomon reigning in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The activities of David the king are recorded in the History of Samuel the Seer, in the History of Nathan the Prophet, and in the History of Gad the Seer,
speaker: Narrator

text: including details regarding his reign, his power, the circumstances that attended his life, Israel, and all of the kingdoms of the countries that surrounded him.
speaker: Narrator
